ARGUS RATING: BUY.snippet: Advanced Micro Devices posted 4Q22 non-GAAP results that exceeded guidance and consensus estimates
Total revenue was up 16% in 4Q22 despite weak client (PC) demand
AMD posted a 16% annual decline in non-GAAP EPS for 4Q22
AMD's client (PC) segment sales in 4Q22 were half the level of 4Q21 sales
Worldwide PC unit sales declined 29% in 4Q22 on top of a 15% decline in 3Q22
AMD's cautious 1Q23 guidance on revenue reflects the challenging environment
Demand will likely remain weak into early 2023
We look for sequential recovery as the year progresses

INVESTMENT THESIS.snippet: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. rose 7% on 2/1/23 after delivering results that exceeded 4Q22 guidance.
AMD's client (PC) segment sales in 4Q22 were half the level of 4Q21 sales.
PC demand will likely remain weak into early 2023.
AMD's cautious 1Q23 revenue growth and gross margin guidance reflects the challenging environment.
Gaming-related sales declined year over year due to inflationary pressure and aging gaming consoles.
Embedded has become a $4.5 billion annual business for AMD.
Data Center is now a $6 billion annual business driven by market share gains for AMD's EPYC server CPUs.
AMD has gained meaningful global market share in CPUs for the data center and client space.
AMD delivered full-year 2022 revenue growth of 44%.
Market Data Pricing reflects previous trading week's closing price.

Argus Recommendations.snippet: Argus assigns a 12-month BUY, HOLD, or SELL rating to each stock under coverage.
BUY-rated stocks are expected to outperform the market on a risk-adjusted basis over the next year.
HOLD-rated stocks are expected to perform in line with the market.
SELL-rated stocks are expected to underperform the market on a risk-adjusted basis.
The distribution of ratings across Argus' entire company universe is: 71% Buy, 28% Hold, 0% Sell.

Key Statistics.snippet: Key Statistics pricing data reflects previous trading day's closing price.
Market Overview includes price and target price data.
The sector rating is MARKET WEIGHT.
Total % of S&P 500 Market Cap is 25.00%.
1 Year Dividend Growth Forecast is N/A.

Analyst's Notes...Continued.snippet: There are multi-year gains in market share.
The early 2023 growth outlook is uncertain.
Share gains in client and data center positions AMD for long-term growth.
AMD announced that Jean Hu is joining as CFO.
Jean Hu replaces Devinder Kumar as CFO.
Hu has served in CFO roles at QLogic, Conexant, and Marvell.
The share price does not fully reflect AMD's long-term revenue and margin growth potential.
Ongoing market share gains are at Intel's expense.
The target price is $100.
2022 was a strong year for AMD, despite challenges.
Data Center and Embedded product sales reached $10.6 billion in 2022, up from $3.9 billion in 2021.
Data Center revenue of $1.66 billion was up 42% year-over-year in 4Q22.
Data Center operating profit of $444 million rose 20% from a year earlier.
Segment margin tightened to 26.8% in 4Q22 from 31.7% in 4Q21.
Data Center growth in 4Q22 was led by EPYC microprocessor sales.
Cloud sales to North American customers more than doubled year over year.
Enterprise revenue declined year-over-year as demand slowed.
AMD closed several new wins in 4Q22 with Fortune 500 companies.
AMD launched its latest-generation Ryzen series notebook processors in January.
The latest Ryzen processors feature AI capabilities.
Gaming revenue was $1.64 billion, down 7% year-over-year.
Gaming operating profit was $269 million, down 35% from the year-earlier holiday quarter.
Gaming segment margin declined from 23.1% for 4Q21 to 16.2% in 4Q22.
The Gaming segment primarily includes discreet graphics processing units (GPUs) under the Radeon name along with semi-custom SoC products and development services.
In 4Q22, lower gaming graphics sales more than offset higher semi-custom revenue.
Semi-custom SoC revenue 'remained strong' in the holiday quarter.
Console scarcity beginning in the pandemic has resulted in significant pent-up demand that carried into holiday sales.
Embedded revenue of \(\) 1.40 billion (25\%) of total rose from \(71\) million a year earlier.
Embedded operating profit was \(699\) million compared to \(18\) million a year earlier.
Segment margin was \(50.0\%\) in 4Q22 vs. \(25.4\%\) for 4Q21.
Sales of acquired Xilinx product families are growing because AMD has brought additional manufacturing scales and marketing resources to these products.
Key categories served, including aerospace-defense, industrial, medical, and semiconductor test & measurement, all grew in the quarter; several categories achieved record sales.
AMD recently announced multiple new wins in automotive areas including ADAS and LiDAR for semi-autonomous driving.
Integration after closing Xilinx has gone extremely well.
AMD overall is positioned to grow revenue and gain share in 2023.
AMD looks for a stronger second half than first half in 2023, with diversified strength across data center, gaming, and embedded.
AMD has been betting heavily on nontraditional businesses, including embedded, micro-server, and semi-custom (gaming console).
AMD is supporting both stand-alone CPU and GPU lines as well as its APU line that combines compute and graphics processing on a single die.

RECENT DEVELOPMENTS.snippet: AMD is up 16% year-to-date in 2023
The peer group is up 15% in 2023
AMD declined 55% in 2022
The Argus semiconductor peer group fell 36% in 2022
AMD advanced 57% in 2021
The peer group gained 34% in 2021
AMD rose 100% in 2020
Peers advanced 49% in 2020
AMD was up 148% in 2019
Peers were up 54% in 2019
AMD rose 80% in 2018
Peers declined 4% in 2018
AMD was a sub-$2 stock in 2015
Advanced Micro Devices reported revenue of $6.0 billion for 4Q22
Revenue was up 16% year-over-year and 1% sequentially for 4Q22
Revenue exceeded the high end of the guidance range of $5.2 - $5.8 billion
Revenue was nearly half a billion dollars above the consensus estimate of $5.5 billion
Non-GAAP profit totaled $0.69 per diluted share for 4Q22
Non-GAAP profit was down 25% from $0.92 a year earlier and up $0.01 sequentially
AMD management does not provide explicit EPS guidance
The Street had projected non-GAAP EPS of $0.67
As of mid-year 2022, AMD had delivered a long string of record quarters
AMD powered through the pandemic and the supply chain crisis
AMD took share in multiple end-markets
The acquisition of Xilinx positioned AMD to build on existing strength
AMD has a growing presence in data center markets
The emergence of inflation at 40-year highs has changed global consumer spending patterns
Inflation has had a particularly intense impact in the consumer electronics space
Consumer weakness has spilled into the enterprise, carrier, and cloud data-center end markets
AMD was able to offset some of the weakness in the client space with strong product sales in data center and embedded processing
CEO Lisa Su thanked former CFO Devinder Kumar for 39 years at AMD
Incoming CFO Jean Hu was welcomed by CEO Lisa Su
Lisa Su has served as CFO at QLogic, Conexant, and Marvell
Lisa Su has served in the CFO role for the past 14 years

Financial & Risk Analysis.snippet: Cash in millions increased from $1,466 in 2019 to $2,535 in 2021
Working Capital in millions increased from $2,238 in 2019 to $4,343 in 2021
Current Ratio was 1.95 in 2019 and 2.02 in 2021
LT Debt/Equity Ratio decreased from 24.2% in 2019 to 4.7% in 2021
Total Debt/Equity Ratio decreased from 24.2% in 2019 to 8.8% in 2021
Gross Profit Margin increased from 42.6% in 2019 to 48.2% in 2021
Operating Margin increased from 9.4% in 2019 to 22.2% in 2021
Net Margin increased from 5.1% in 2019 to 19.2% in 2021
Return On Assets decreased from 6.4% in 2019 to 29.6% in 2021
Return On Equity decreased from 16.7% in 2019 to 47.4% in 2021
Cash Cycle increased from 84.1 days in 2019 to 86.6 days in 2021
Cash Flow/Cap Ex increased from 2.3 in 2019 to 11.7 in 2021
Oper. Income/Int. Exp. increased from 5.0 in 2019 to 108.9 in 2021

Peer & Industry Analysis.snippet: The graphics in this section are designed to allow investors to compare AMD versus its industry peers, the broader sector, and the market as a whole
The scatterplot shows how AMD stacks up versus its peers on two key characteristics: long-term growth and value
Companies in the lower left-hand corner are more value-oriented, while those in the upper right-hand corner are more growth-oriented
The table builds on the scatterplot by displaying more financial information
The bar charts on the right take the analysis two steps further, by broadening the comparison groups into the sector level and the market as a whole
This tool is designed to help investors understand how AMD might fit into or modify a diversified portfolio
AMD now powers more than 100 of the world's fastest supercomputers
15 of the 20 most energy-efficient supercomputers are powered by AMD
In November, AMD introduced its fourth-generation EPYC processor family
The fourth-generation EPYC processor family delivers twice the performance with an 80% energy-efficiency boost compared to prior iterations
Customer response has been positive, though likely tempered by the current environment
Client revenue of $903 million (16% of total) declined 51% annually and 12% sequentially for 4Q22
Client posted an operating loss of $152 million for 4Q22, down from a profit of $530 million a year earlier
The Client business was also unprofitable in sequentially adjacent 3Q22
Client includes CPUs, accelerated processing units (APUs), and chipsets for desktop and notebook PCs
Demand weakness was most intense in consumer channels, the entire PC space has slowed dramatically
Worldwide PC unit sales declined 29% in 4Q22 on top of a 15% decline in 3Q22 according to IDC
The consumer and notebook distribution channel remains cautious
AMD continued to ship units below actual PC consumption in the fourth quarter
AMD is helping channel partners further reduce inventory
AMD has delivered multiple new products

EARNINGS & GROWTH ANALYSIS.snippet: For 4Q22, Advanced Micro Devices reported revenue of 6.0 billion.
Revenue for 4Q22 was up 16% year-over-year.
Revenue for 4Q22 was up 1% sequentially.
Revenue included a full contribution from Xilinx.
Revenue exceeded the high end of the guidance range of 5.2-5.8 billion.
Revenue was nearly half a billion dollars above the consensus estimate of 5.5 billion.
Non-GAAP gross margin was 51.1% for 4Q22.
Non-GAAP gross margin was 49.9% for 3Q22.
Non-GAAP gross margin was 50.3% a year earlier.
Gross margin gains reflected a better mix (fewer consumer PCs).
Non-GAAP operating margin was 22.5% for 3Q22.
Non-GAAP operating margin was 22.7% for 2Q22.
Non-GAAP operating margin was 27.5% a year earlier.
Non-GAAP profit totaled 0.69 per diluted share.
Non-GAAP profit was down 25% from 0.92 a year earlier.
Non-GAAP profit was up 0.01 sequentially.
Management does not provide explicit EPS guidance.
The Street had projected non-GAAP EPS of 0.67.
For 2022, revenue of 23.6 billion rose 44% from 16.4 billion for 2021.
Non-GAAP EPS for 2022 was 3.54, up 26% from 2.81 a year earlier.
For 1Q23, AMD guided for revenue of 5.0-5.6 billion.
At the 5.3 billion midpoint, revenue would be down 10% annually.
Revenue at the 5.3 billion midpoint would be down 5% from 4Q22.
The adjusted gross margin is forecast at 50% for 1Q23.
Adjusted gross margin is compared with 52.7% a year earlier.
AMD's 1Q23 guidance is consistent with EPS in the 0.60-0.80 range.
EPS was compared to 1.13 a year earlier.
We are lowering our 2023 non-GAAP estimate to 3.49 per diluted share.
We are implementing a non-GAAP EPS forecast for 2024 of 5.10 per diluted share.
Estimates are fluid and subject to revision due to uncertain economic outlook.
Five-year non-GAAP annualized EPS growth rate forecast remains 15%.
Forecast remains among the highest in Argus Technology coverage.

FINANCIAL STRENGTH & DIVIDEND.snippet: AMD's financial strength rating is Medium-High
AMD has successfully restructured its debt to reduce interest costs
AMD has swung to a net cash position from a net debt position
AMD stepped up shareholder returns
The acquisition of Xilinx should add net cash of about 2.2 billion
AMD's cash was 5.91 billion at the end of 2022
Cash was 3.61 billion at the end of 2021
Cash was 2.29 billion at the end of 2020
Cash was 1.50 billion at the end of 2019
Cash was 1.08 billion at year-end 2018
Total debt was 2.47 billion as of the end of 2022
Debt was 313 million as of the end of 2021
Debt was 330 million as of the end of 2020
Debt was 685 million at the end of 2019
Debt was 1.25 billion at year-end 2018
Net cash was 3.45 billion at the end of 2022
Net cash was 3.29 billion at the end of 2021
Net cash was 1.96 billion at the end of 2020
Net cash was 818 million at the end of 2019
AMD was in a net debt position for multiple years prior to mid-2019
Net debt was 172 million at year-end 2018
Net debt was 210 million at year-end 2017
Cash flow from operations was 3.57 billion in 2022
Cash flow from operations was 3.52 billion in 2021
Cash flow from operations was 1.07 billion in 2020
Cash flow from operations was 493 million in 2019
Cash flow from operations was 34 million in 2018
AMD announced an 8 billion share-repurchase authorization in May 2022
AMD had previously announced a 4 billion share-repurchase authorization in 2021
Share repurchases were primarily used to offset dilution from stock-based compensation
We do not expect AMD to pay a dividend in 2023 or 2024

MANAGEMENT & RISKS.snippet: Lisa Su became CEO in October 2014
Lisa Su was recently elevated to chairman of the board
AMD announced that Jean Hu is joining the company as CFO in January 2023
Jean Hu replaces Devinder Kumar, who is retiring
Jean Hu has served in the CFO role
Jean Hu has served as interim CEO at times

COMPANY DESCRIPTION.snippet: Advanced Micro Devices is the number-two player in x86-based microprocessors, behind Intel.
Advanced Micro Devices is a top player in graphic processors.
Advanced Micro Devices acquired Xilinx in 2021.
The acquisition of Xilinx expanded Advanced Micro Devices' presence in embedded computing and data center.

VALUATION.snippet: AMD shares are trading at 21.5-times our 2023 non-GAAP EPS estimate
AMD shares are trading at 14.7-times our 2024 projection
AMD trades at a two-year forward P/E of 18.1
The two-year-forward relative P/E of 1.05 is just above the market P/E
The historical average for 2018-2021 for AMD's P/E is 2.19
Historical comparable valuation for AMD indicates value in the low $200
Peer group analysis suggests that AMD deserves to trade at a premium to peers
The peer-indicated value for AMD is in the $90
The peer-indicated value for AMD is down from a late 2021 peak in the $160
Our discounted free cash flow model renders a fair value in the $150
The fair value of AMD is down from past peaks on slowing PC momentum
Blending these approaches, we arrive at a value above $150
The client market is likely to remain volatile in the near term
EPYC is making progress in cloud and enterprise data center
The Ryzen CPUs are successful for desktop and notebook PCs
The outlook for AMD's Radeon GPUs in PC gaming is positive
The XLNX deal is regarded as a logical next step in AMD's journey
The XLNX deal adds high-growth complementary assets for AMD
AMD's growth in the cloud data center will be accelerated by the XLNX deal
AMD has slipped from its highs on consumer demand softness
Current prices do not fully reflect AMD's revenue and margin growth potential
AMD is gaining market share at Intel's expense
We are reiterating our BUY rating to a 12-month target price of $100
On February 1 at midday, BUY-rated AMD traded at $80.48, up $5.33

About Argus.snippet: Argus Research was founded by Economist Harold Dorsey in 1934
Argus has built a top-down, fundamental system used by Argus analysts
The Argus analysis system includes six points: Industry Analysis, Growth Analysis, Financial Strength Analysis, Management Assessment, Risk Analysis and Valuation Analysis
The Industry Analysis identifies industries expected to perform well over the next one- to-two years using forecasts from Argus' Economist
The Growth Analysis generates proprietary estimates for companies under coverage
In the Financial Strength Analysis, analysts study ratios to understand profitability, liquidity and capital structure
During the Management Assessment, analysts meet with corporate management teams
Quantitative trends and qualitative threats are assessed under the Risk Analysis
Argus' Valuation Analysis model integrates a historical ratio matrix, discounted cash flow modeling, and peer comparison

THE ARGUS RESEARCH RATING SYSTEM.snippet: Argus uses three ratings for stocks: BUY, HOLD, and SELL.
Stocks are rated relative to a benchmark, the S&P 500.
A BUY-rated stock is expected to outperform the S&P 500 on a risk-adjusted basis over a 12-month period.
Argus Analysts set target prices and use beta as the measure of risk.
Argus Analysts compare expected risk-adjusted stock returns to the S&P 500 forecasts set by the Argus Market Strategist.
A HOLD-rated stock is expected to perform in line with the S&P 500.
A SELL-rated stock is expected to underperform the S&P 500.
